meeting_annotations.speaker: Linnea Freeman- Furman University
meeting_annotations.transcript: I usually focus on obesity and bacteroidities goes down typically. That's not like that's the challenge with this too. But going down that um discussion of inflammatory response, I just like I have so many questions about how that really works because for looking at diversity of community, like there are just so many changes that are happening and it doesn't always I mean I guess this connects with that correlation causation group but it just doesn't always translate to here's a dysbiosis if we want to call it that or just a difference for looking person to person or age group to age group. I don't always see that it could add up to an increase in all of the bacteria that are going to contribute to an increased inflammatory response. Like there's just ups and downs and it's um maybe like some compensation where it doesn't always equal chronic inflammation. Like I think that's coming from other sources too and maybe this is just stoking that fire but it just seems to me like there's um more of a connection with the quote unquote dysbiosis, like some sort of change from what it used to be way what the system was used to it being and then connecting more with metabolites and the response to that than it would be categorizing the types of bacteria as being LPS producing or something like that.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer | Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: How are they changing over age? You know, I don't know the answer actually. I don't know the answer. I know what happens from early life but I don't know very old life. So in early life, um there our bodies have different source of macrophage. There are embryonic macrophages that that live all over your body. Many tissues keep these embryonic derived macrophages forever. And the gut is different that they basically get out competed very quickly as soon as the microbes come in. They get out competed by monocyte derived macrophage. So I do know there is a pretty rapid replacement of embryonic macrophage with bone marrow conventional, you know, what we think of conventional monocyte derived macrophage in the gut, that's for sure. As far as how those change over time in old, I don't know. But but they do know that there are some macrophage subsets that are far more long lived as compared to others. And if they look at um like small small bowel transplant recipients, they can find macrophages from the donor tissue in those humans that trans that got that transplanted bowel, they can find those like a year later. So some of them do live very long time.
